H0.text: when did the us stop trading with japan. 1937

H1.text: when did the us stop trading with japan. 1939

H2.text: when did the us stop trading with japan. 1941

H3.text: when did the us stop trading with japan. 1940

A4.text: The United States finally ceased oil exports to Japan in July 1941

A5.text: In 1940, the United States halted shipments of airplanes, parts, machine tools, and aviation gasoline to Japan

A6.text: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt orders the freezing of all Japanese assets in the United States.

A8.text: The U.S. government passed the Export Control Act in July 1940, cutting oil, iron and steel exports to Japan.

A9.text: In 1939, the United States notified Japan it would not extend its trade treaty and imposed the Export Control Acts, banning US exports of chemicals, minerals and military parts to Japan.

A10.text: The United States, the United Kingdom, and other Western governments reacted to this move with a freeze on Japanese assets and a total oil embargo.
